results.question: What method did the company use when Topic 606 in fiscal 2019 was adopted?
results.markdown_table_response: We use a modified retrospective method to estimate the effect of Topic 606 on our current accounting policies and practices. Our modified retrospective method is based on the adjusted closing balance of our Consolidated Balance Sheet, which we recorded on May 26, 2019. The adjusted closing balance is a variable that reflects changes to the current liabilities of our Consolidated Balance Sheet and is calculated as the difference between the current liabilities and the assets that are currently reported in the Consolidated Balance Sheet. In addition, we adjusted the closing balance of our Consolidated Balance Sheet to reflect the timing of the adoption of Topic 606.

results.question: What led to lower capital expenditures at Bell Media in 2019?
gold_answer: production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018
results.markdown_table_response:
A reduction in capital expenditures at Bell Media in 2019 was due to several factors. The following were the main factors:
• We focused our investments on delivering wireless network capabilities in our core markets and on upgrading our existing facilities, which had been built at a high cost.
• We implemented new business and marketing and sales and marketing strategies, which reduced our expenses.
• We continued to invest in infrastructure and systems upgrades, which reduced our capital expenditures.
results.csv_string_response: The following factors were contributing to lower capital expenditures at Bell Media in 2019:
results.json_rows_response:
The capital spending reductions in the year were primarily a result of the following:
• A reduction in capital spending of $3 million in 2019, reflecting a reduction in wireless small-cell build-out and the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec
• A reduction in capital spending of $10 million in 2019, reflecting the roll-out of FTTP to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• A reduction in capital expenditures of $6 million in 2019, reflecting the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec

results.question: What is the $ change in the capital expenditures for Bell Wireless?

The capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million in 2019, up $17 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6%, down 0.3 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital expenditures at Bell Media of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to last year, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

The increase in sales was primarily driven by growth in both organic and inorganic business in North America. Sales in 2019 were higher in the U.S. primarily due to system development on contracts in New York, Boston, and the San Francisco Bay Area. Businesses acquired by CTS during fiscal year 2019, whose operations are all located in the U.S., had sales of $74.4 million in fiscal year 2019. Sales were lower in the UK primarily due to a decrease in system development work in London and the negative impact of currency exchange rates. The average exchange rates between the prevailing currencies in our foreign operations and the U.S. dollar resulted in a decrease in CTS sales of $22.2 million for 2019 compared to 2018, primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the British pound and Australian dollar.
